newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Hamanaka arrest triggers yawns in copper market.
newsitem.headline: Hamanaka arrest triggers yawns in copper market.

text.p: Base metal traders said on Tuesday the arrest and prosecution for forgery of Sumitomo Corp's dismissed chief copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka would have little impact on the copper market.
"What difference will it make?" Vinod Kumar, director of Singapore-based metal company Donald Mcarthy, told Reuters. "Whatever has been done cannot be undone. It should have no impact, absolutely."
"Hamanaka hasn't been in the pit since he was sacked in June, so he has no impact on the market," a metals dealer in Sydney said.
"The Hamanaka affair is over as far as the market is concerned. The market will just ignore this," a dealer in a Japanese metal trading company agreed.

Prosecutors in Tokyo told reporters Hamanaka, fired last June for his role in Sumitomo's estimated $2.6 billion copper trading loss, was arrested on Tuesday on two counts of forging documents for use in trading non-ferrous metals.
"After everything else is settled, now they launch a raid?" one trader said.
Far East metal traders said the market was paying attention more to the possibility of another large drawdown in copper stocks similar to the 19,125-tonne fall in the LME report last Friday.
In London on Tuesday, LME copper stocks went down by 13,075 tonnes while aluminium stocks fell by 2,875 tonnes.
Three month copper prices were stable around $1,960 a tonne in London in early trade on Tuesday. Copper had been quoted at around $1,960/65 a tonne by Singapore metal traders at 0800 GMT.
Aluminium prices in London were stable just above $1,350 a tonne, little changed from the $1,350/55 a tonne quoted in Singapore at about 0800 GMT, metal dealers said.
